Issues.Title: refactor: use relative FieldPathNodes
Issues.Body:
Switch `apply` behavior to create a brand new root path whenever a new schema is applied. This effectively changes our `FieldPathNode` concept from an absolute path to a relative path.

To record how the relative path nodes are connected, introduce a `rootPaths` map to each logic node, and when we `apply`, copy all roots from the sub-schema to the root of the current schema. This results in the top-level schema having a mapping to all roots under it, allowing it to construct the full absolute path.

Issues.Title: Data Caching Issue on Page Refresh in Angular SSR with NGINX
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

**Description of the issue:**

In an Angular SSR (Server-Side Rendering) application, there is an issue where outdated data is returned when refreshing the page. It seems that Angular might be caching the initial API data during the SSR build, and then repeatedly displaying this cached data even after page refresh. However, when navigating between routes, the data loads correctly.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. The application is running with Angular SSR, proxied through NGINX.
2. Caching is disabled for API via headers in NGINX:
    ```nginx
    add_header Cache-Control 'no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, proxy-revalidate';
    add_header Pragma 'no-cache';
    expires off;
    etag off;
    ```
3. When refreshing the page in the browser, old (cached) data is returned.
4. When navigating between routes in the app, data is loaded correctly.

**Expected behavior:**
On page refresh, the data should update and display the latest version, just as it does when navigating between routes.

**Current behavior:**
Upon page refresh, data does not update and shows stale values. The issue does not occur when navigating between routes within the app.

**Technical details:**
- **NGINX** is used as a reverse proxy for both the frontend and API.
- **Angular SSR** is used for server-side rendering.
- The issue occurs only when refreshing the page, not when navigating within the app.
- All caching headers are disabled on the NGINX server:
    ```nginx
    proxy_cache off;
    add_header Cache-Control 'no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, proxy-revalidate';
    add_header Pragma 'no-cache';
    expires off;
    etag off;
    ```

**Additional questions/clarifications:**
- This issue only concerns the behavior on page refresh (not route navigation).
- It is unclear whether the caching is occurring on the Angular SSR side or at the API level, despite the NGINX settings to disable caching.
- It would also be helpful to investigate if browser caching could be affecting the data display.

**Expected outcome:**
It would be helpful to understand what caching mechanisms might be causing outdated data to persist on the server-side or within Angular SSR, despite the cache control settings in NGINX.

Issues.Title: fix(core): reduce total memory usage of various migration schematics
Issues.Body:
This commit changes Tsurge's operation within angular-devkit (i.e. the CLI) to no longer retain all programs across all migrations. This isn't necessary for so-called "funnel" migrations so not retaining the programs for those migrations is a pure performance win. The "complex" migrations may see increased execution time given that the program is now being recreated for the actual migration phase to run, although reduced memory pressure may help alleviate this overhead. Since this new approach should help prevent Node from running out of memory and failing entirely this is preferred over a potentially increased execution time.

Fixes #59813

Issues.Title: Feature Request: Debounce in signal / httpResource
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

I want to make a get API call whenever the user searches but with a debounce time in httpResource.

I am open to contributing a PR for this, I wanted to know if this is a right thing to ask and if yes then I wanted to discuss which approach would be the best

### Proposed solution

I could think of these 2 solutions, let me know if there's anything better: 
1. debounceTrack function similar to untracked function
2. debounce property in the options of signal primitive

### Alternatives considered

There is a workaround to do this -> toSignal(toObservable(searchSignal()).pipe(debounceTime(500)))

2 Reasons I am not doing this:

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): add update migration to keep previous style guide generation behavior
Issues.Body:
When updating to Angular v20 via `ng update`, a migration will be executed that will add schematic generation (`ng generate`) defaults to the workspace. These defaults will ensure that existing projects will continue to generate files as done in previous versions of the Angular CLI. All new projects (via `ng new`) or projects that do not explicitly contain these options in their workspace will use the updated style guide naming behavior.

The option values for the `schematics` field are as follows:
```
{
    '@schematics/angular:component': { type: 'component' },
    '@schematics/angular:directive': { type: 'directive' },
    '@schematics/angular:service': { type: 'service' },
    '@schematics/angular:guard': { typeSeparator: '.' },
    '@schematics/angular:interceptor': { typeSeparator: '.' },
    '@schematics/angular:module': { typeSeparator: '.' },
    '@schematics/angular:pipe': { typeSeparator: '.' },
    '@schematics/angular:resolver': { typeSeparator: '.' },
}
```

Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

In Angular 17, I utilized a loader to process `.glb` files as assets. This setup functioned smoothly in both development and production environments, with the files being correctly copied to the designated asset directory during production builds. I `acrchitect.build.options`

```json
"loader": {
  ".glb": "file"
}
```

Upon upgrading to Angular 19, the loader configuration ceased to work in development mode, although it remains functional in production. In production, the application operates without issues, and the `.glb` files are successfully transferred to the asset directory.

The file is imported using the following statement:

```typescript
import GizmoCircles from "ria-toolbox/libs/scene-navigation/gizmo/gizmo_circles.glb";
```

However, in development mode, I encounter a console warning:

```
Cannot optimize dependency: ria-toolbox/libs/scene-navigation/gizmo/gizmo_arrows.glb, present in client 'optimizeDeps.include'
```

Additionally, the browser displays the following error:

```
[plugin:vite:import-analysis] Failed to parse source for import analysis because the content contains invalid JS syntax. You may need to install appropriate plugins to handle the .glb file format, or if it's an asset, add "**/*.glb" to `assetsInclude` in your configuration.
D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/ria-toolbox/libs/scene-navigation/gizmo/gizmo_circles.glb
```

As a consequence, the application crashes, rendering the development environment unusable.

_No response_

```true
    at TransformPluginContext._formatLog (file:///D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/@angular/build/node_modules/vite/dist/node/chunks/dep-DrOo5SEf.js:47867:41)
    at TransformPluginContext.error (file:///D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/@angular/build/node_modules/vite/dist/node/chunks/dep-DrOo5SEf.js:47864:16)
    at TransformPluginContext.transform (file:///D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/@angular/build/node_modules/vite/dist/node/chunks/dep-DrOo5SEf.js:45949:14)
    at async EnvironmentPluginContainer.transform (file:///D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/@angular/build/node_modules/vite/dist/node/chunks/dep-DrOo5SEf.js:47662:18)
    at async loadAndTransform (file:///D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/@angular/build/node_modules/vite/dist/node/chunks/dep-DrOo5SEf.js:41320:27)
    at async viteTransformMiddleware (file:///D:/luciadriatraining/toolbox/angular-toolbox-sample/node_modules/@angular/build/node_modules/vite/dist/node/chunks/dep-DrOo5SEf.js:42796:24
```

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 19.0.0
Node: 22.11.0

OS: win32 x64

Angular:

Package                      Version
------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect    0.1900.0 (cli-only)

@schematics/angular          19.0.0 (cli-only)
```

### Anything else?

The code functions flawlessly in Angular 17 in both production and development environments.

However, after upgrading to Angular 19, the application fails to load `.glb` files in development mode, causing it to crash. In contrast, it operates as expected in production.

Since the error message displayed is:

```
[plugin:vite:import-analysis] Failed to parse source for import.
```

This suggests there may be an issue with the development server's implementation with vite for loading files in development mode.

The GLB files I use are around 100kb and are in binary format if this adds some useful info

In this PR https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/29753 there was a regression that now prevents corrent handling of external local dependencies. Issues.Title: feat(dialog): Full-screen dialog
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

#### Overview
This feature request proposes adding a full-screen display option to the existing Angular Material Dialog component. This enhancement would allow dialogs to expand to occupy the entire viewport, providing a more immersive experience for content-heavy dialogs while maintaining the existing Dialog API.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f0eea513-124c-4de1-af8d-6f20db23351d)

#### Problem Statement
The current Angular Material Dialog component is limited to fixed or responsive sizing within the viewport. While this works well for typical dialog use cases, there are scenarios where a full-screen dialog would provide a better user experience.

Developers currently work around this limitation by:
- Creating custom full-screen components outside the Dialog system
- Using CSS hacks to force dialogs to expand beyond their intended size
- Implementing non-standard patterns that break Material Design guidelines

These workarounds lead to inconsistent implementations, maintenance overhead, and potential accessibility issues.

#### Proposed Solution
Enhance the MatDialog service and related components to support a new `fullScreen` configuration option that, when enabled, renders the dialog at 100% width and height of the viewport, with appropriate transitions and behaviors aligned with Material Design principles.

#### References
- [Material Design Dialog component](https://m3.material.io/components/dialogs/overview)

### Use Case

- Complex forms
- Detail views with rich content or multiple sections
- Mobile-friendly interfaces
- Media viewers (images, videos, documents)
- Workflow wizards with complex steps
- Rich text editors
- Content creation interfaces

### Feature Description

#### Overview
This feature request proposes adding a Carousel component to the Angular Material library. The Carousel would allow users to browse through a collection of items in a horizontal sliding interface.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0c03e117-93c5-484d-8b19-486e72a17f67)

#### Problem Statement
Angular Material currently lacks a dedicated Carousel component, forcing developers to:
- Implement custom carousel solutions
- Rely on third-party libraries that may not adhere to Material Design principles
- Create inconsistent user experiences across applications using Angular Material

This gap in the component library leads to fragmentation in the ecosystem and requires teams to invest development time in solving a common UI pattern that should be standardized.

#### Proposed Solution
Introduce a new `mat-carousel` component that follows Material Design guidelines while providing a flexible, accessible, and performant implementation for displaying sequential content.

Issues.Title: refactor(google-maps): tree-shake `assertInitialized`
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, in production bundles, `assertInitialized` is an empty method (its body is guarded with `ngDevMode`) that is preserved on the class and always called. There's no reason to keep calling no-op methods in production. This also increases bundle size because the method itself is not tree-shaken.

In this commit, the assertion has been moved to a separate function, which can be dropped in production due to the `ngDevMode` guard.

The only downside I couldn't resolve is that assertion functions (`asserts ...`) can't be used in this setup, so I had to use the non-null assertion operator instead.
